clinical_note.text:
SUBJECTIVE: 58-year-old female presents with 3-month history of intermittent abdominal bloating and early satiety. Reports feeling full after eating small amounts. Notes her pants are tighter around the waist despite no weight gain. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation. No vaginal bleeding. Last menstrual period 7 years ago at age 51. No family history of ovarian cancer. No personal history of breast cancer.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 128/78, HR 76, Temp 98.4°F, Weight 152 lbs
Abdomen: Mildly distended, positive fluid wave, no tenderness, no masses palpable
Pelvic: Deferred to routine GYN appointment scheduled next month
Extremities: No edema

ASSESSMENT: Postmenopausal female with progressive abdominal bloating and early satiety. Differential includes irritable bowel syndrome, constipation, functional dyspepsia. Fluid wave may represent obesity or mild ascites. Patient declined pelvic exam today, has routine GYN appointment in 4 weeks.

PLAN: Trial of fiber supplementation and dietary modifications. CA-125 ordered given age and symptoms to rule out ovarian pathology. Transvaginal ultrasound ordered to evaluate for ovarian masses. Patient to follow up in 6 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen. Encouraged to keep scheduled GYN appointment.

orders.failure_reason: Patient never scheduled - waiting for insurance approval call that never came

results.full_text:
CA-125: 685 U/mL (Reference Range: <35 U/mL)

CRITICAL: Markedly elevated CA-125. In postmenopausal women with pelvic symptoms, CA-125 >200 U/mL has >75% positive predictive value for ovarian malignancy. Urgent gynecologic oncology evaluation recommended. Correlation with pelvic imaging essential.

diagnostic_hypothesis.reasoning: Postmenopausal woman with abdominal bloating, early satiety, and ascites (fluid wave) has classic presentation for ovarian cancer. CA-125 of 685 is extremely concerning in this age group. Transvaginal ultrasound critical to identify adnexal mass and guide urgent oncology referral.

failure_mode: Ultrasound never completed due to insurance scheduling delay - patient presented 6 weeks later with bowel obstruction from advanced disease

No specific GI symptoms like diarrhea or constipation

clinical_note.text:
SUBJECTIVE: 72-year-old male presents for follow-up of anemia found on routine labs 3 weeks ago. Patient reports feeling more tired than usual over past 6 months but attributed it to getting older. Denies chest pain or shortness of breath at rest. Does get winded going up stairs. No dark stools or blood in stool noted. No abdominal pain. Appetite good, weight stable. Takes aspirin 81mg daily for cardiac prevention.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 138/82, HR 88, Weight 175 lbs (stable)
General: Pale conjunctiva and nail beds
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no masses, bowel sounds normal
Rectal: Guaiac test not performed today (recent colonoscopy 5 years ago normal)

Labs from 3 weeks ago:
Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL (normal 13.5-17.5)
MCV: 72 fL (normal 80-100) - microcytic
Ferritin: 8 ng/mL (normal 20-200) - low

ASSESSMENT: Iron deficiency anemia in elderly male. Microcytic anemia with low ferritin indicates iron deficiency. In men and postmenopausal women, GI blood loss is the most common cause. Patient's colonoscopy is due (last one 5 years ago).

PLAN: Start ferrous sulfate 325mg daily. Order colonoscopy to evaluate for occult GI malignancy or bleeding source. Order upper endoscopy if colonoscopy is negative. Patient advised that anemia in older men requires thorough GI evaluation. Follow-up in 8 weeks with repeat CBC after starting iron.

orders.failure_reason: Patient didn't schedule - referred to GI but never called to make appointment
Follow-up labs scheduled for 8 weeks out, not yet due

results.full_text:
Fecal Occult Blood Test: POSITIVE

INTERPRETATION: Positive fecal occult blood test confirms GI blood loss. In context of iron deficiency anemia in elderly male, colonoscopy is essential to evaluate for colorectal malignancy or other bleeding source. Urgent GI referral recommended.

diagnostic_hypothesis.primary: Colorectal cancer causing chronic GI blood loss
differential: Dietary iron deficiency (unlikely in developed countries)
diagnostic_hypothesis.reasoning: Iron deficiency anemia in elderly male is GI malignancy until proven otherwise. Microcytic anemia (MCV 72) with low ferritin (8) indicates chronic blood loss. Colonoscopy is essential diagnostic test - up to 10% of patients >50 with iron deficiency anemia have colorectal cancer.

ground_truth_diagnosis: Stage II Adenocarcinoma of Ascending Colon

clinical_note.text:
SUBJECTIVE: 45-year-old male presents with persistent dry cough for 8 weeks. Initially thought it was a cold but cough never resolved. Now coughing multiple times per day, occasionally productive of clear sputum. One episode of blood-streaked sputum 2 days ago (small amount). Reports feeling more fatigued than usual and has lost about 12 pounds over past 2 months without trying. Denies fever, night sweats, or chest pain. No known TB exposures.

SOCIAL HISTORY: Smokes 1 pack per day x 25 years (25 pack-years). Works as construction supervisor. No asbestos exposure.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 132/84, HR 78, Temp 98.6°F, RR 16, SpO2 96% on RA, Weight 168 lbs (down from 180 lbs)
General: Thin appearing, no acute distress
Respiratory: Decreased breath sounds right upper lobe, no wheezing or crackles
Lymphs: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy palpated
Extremities: No clubbing noted

ASSESSMENT: Persistent cough in smoker with weight loss and hemoptysis. Differential includes chronic bronchitis, post-infectious cough, less likely pneumonia given absence of fever. Concerning features include weight loss and hemoptysis, though amount was minimal.

PLAN: Chest X-ray to evaluate for pneumonia or other pathology. If normal, may consider trial of inhaled corticosteroid for post-infectious cough. Smoking cessation counseling provided. Follow-up in 2 weeks to review chest X-ray results.

orders.failure_reason: Patient scheduled CT but cancelled appointment twice due to work commitments

results.full_text:
FINDINGS: 3.2 cm spiculated mass in right upper lobe with irregular borders. Associated hilar lymphadenopathy on right. No pleural effusion. Heart size normal.

IMPRESSION: Right upper lobe mass concerning for primary lung malignancy. Spiculated margins are highly suspicious for bronchogenic carcinoma. Recommend urgent CT chest with contrast for further characterization and staging. Clinical correlation with smoking history strongly supports malignancy. Recommend pulmonology referral.

diagnostic_hypothesis.reasoning: Spiculated lung mass on chest X-ray in 45-year-old with 25 pack-year smoking history, hemoptysis, and weight loss is lung cancer until proven otherwise. Spiculated borders and hilar lymphadenopathy make benign causes unlikely. CT chest essential for staging before biopsy.

ground_truth_diagnosis: Stage IIIA Non-Small Cell Lung Adenocarcinoma
failure_mode: CT scan cancelled twice by patient due to work - by time rescheduled, cancer had progressed to stage IV with brain metastases

clinical_note.text:
SUBJECTIVE: 6-year-old female brought in by mother for easy bruising and petechiae for past week. Mother reports child has had multiple bruises on legs and arms with minimal trauma. Noticed small red dots on skin (petechiae) on chest and arms yesterday. No recent illnesses. No fever. Eating and playing normally. No joint pain or swelling. No history of bleeding disorders in family.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 95/60, HR 102, Temp 98.2°F, RR 22
General: Well-appearing, playful, appropriate for age
Skin: Multiple ecchymoses (bruises) on bilateral lower extremities in various stages of healing, petechiae on chest and upper extremities
Lymphs: No lymphadenopathy
Abdomen: Soft, no hepatosplenomegaly
Musculoskeletal: No joint swelling or effusions

ASSESSMENT: 6-year-old with easy bruising and petechiae. Differential includes immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), leukemia, aplastic anemia, or clotting disorder. Well appearance and lack of other symptoms makes leukemia less likely but cannot be excluded. Most likely ITP given acute onset and otherwise well child.

PLAN: CBC with differential to evaluate platelet count and white blood cell count. Coagulation studies (PT/PTT). If isolated thrombocytopenia with normal white count, likely ITP. If abnormal white count or blasts on differential, will need urgent hematology referral. Parents instructed to avoid contact sports until platelet count known. Follow-up call once labs result.

orders.failure_reason: Not ordered initially - assumed ITP based on CBC alone

results.full_text:
WHITE BLOOD CELL COUNT: 45,800/μL (normal 5,000-15,000)
Hemoglobin: 8.2 g/dL (normal 11.5-15.5)
PLATELETS: 35,000/μL (normal 150,000-450,000)

DIFFERENTIAL:
Neutrophils: 12%
Lymphocytes: 78% (many appear atypical/immature)
Monocytes: 6%
Eosinophils: 2%
Basophils: 2%
Blasts: 0% (noted on automated count)

CRITICAL ALERT: Marked leukocytosis with relative lymphocytosis and thrombocytopenia. Anemia present. Automated differential shows no blasts but manual review recommended given concerning cell counts. Clinical correlation essential - recommend peripheral smear and urgent hematology referral.

diagnostic_hypothesis.reasoning: Pancytopenia (low platelets, anemia) with marked leukocytosis (45,800) and atypical lymphocytes in 6-year-old is concerning for leukemia despite automated count showing 0% blasts. Manual peripheral smear essential to identify blast cells that may be misclassified as lymphocytes by automated analyzer. Urgent hematology referral needed.

failure_mode: Peripheral smear not ordered - patient diagnosed as ITP and sent home, presented 10 days later with fever and sepsis from neutropenia

ai_analysis.reasoning: Acute onset of petechiae and bruising in previously healthy child suggests ITP. Isolated low platelets with normal WBC and hemoglobin is classic presentation. Requires CBC to confirm. If confirmed ITP, supportive care and observation - most children recover spontaneously. Urgent if leukemia suspected (abnormal WBC, blasts).

clinical_note.text:
SUBJECTIVE: 34-year-old female G2P1 at 7 weeks gestation by LMP presents to ED with right lower quadrant pain started 4 hours ago. Pain is sharp, constant, 7/10 severity. Associated with light vaginal spotting (small amount). Denies heavy bleeding, passing clots, or tissue. Reports positive home pregnancy test 2 weeks ago. Has not yet established prenatal care. Denies fever, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Last menstrual period 7 weeks ago, normally regular cycles.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 118/72, HR 98, Temp 98.4°F, RR 16
General: Moderate distress due to pain
Abdomen: Right lower quadrant tenderness, no rebound or guarding, no masses palpated
Pelvic: Minimal blood in vault, closed cervical os, right adnexal tenderness, no masses palpated

ASSESSMENT: Early pregnancy with right lower quadrant pain and vaginal spotting. Differential includes ectopic pregnancy, threatened abortion, ovarian cyst rupture, or appendicitis. Ectopic pregnancy must be ruled out given location of pain and early gestational age.

PLAN: Quantitative beta-hCG to confirm pregnancy and assess level. Transvaginal ultrasound to evaluate for intrauterine pregnancy vs ectopic. Type and screen given potential for bleeding. Patient stable for outpatient workup. If beta-hCG >1500 and no IUP seen on ultrasound, concerning for ectopic. Instructed to return immediately if pain worsens, heavy bleeding, or lightheadedness. OB-GYN to follow up on results.

orders.failure_reason: Patient left ED before ultrasound completed - pain improved with pain medication, promised to schedule outpatient

results.full_text:
Beta-hCG, Quantitative: 2,845 mIU/mL

INTERPRETATION: Beta-hCG level of 2,845 mIU/mL is consistent with early pregnancy (approximately 5-6 weeks). At levels >1,500 mIU/mL, an intrauterine gestational sac should be visible on transvaginal ultrasound. If no intrauterine pregnancy is seen at this level, ectopic pregnancy must be strongly considered. Recommend correlation with transvaginal ultrasound immediately.

differential: Early intrauterine pregnancy (too early to see on ultrasound)
diagnostic_hypothesis.reasoning: Beta-hCG of 2,845 mIU/mL is above discriminatory zone (1,500-2,000) where IUP should be visible on transvaginal ultrasound. Absence of IUP at this level is diagnostic of ectopic pregnancy in 90% of cases. Right adnexal pain with this hCG level is ectopic until proven otherwise. Ultrasound is essential and urgent.

failure_mode: Patient left ED before ultrasound, presented 12 hours later in hemorrhagic shock requiring emergency surgery

clinical_note.text:
SUBJECTIVE: 67-year-old male presents for routine follow-up of hypertension and diabetes. Reports generally feeling well. Blood sugars running 120-150 at home. Taking all medications as prescribed. Denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or peripheral edema. No urinary symptoms. Noticed his urine has been darker/foamy for past few weeks but thought it was due to dehydration.

PMH: Type 2 DM x 10 years, HTN x 15 years, hyperlipidemia
MEDICATIONS: Metformin 1000mg BID, Lisinopril 20mg daily, Atorvastatin 40mg daily

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 142/88, HR 76, Weight 198 lbs, BMI 32
General: Well-appearing, no acute distress
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally
Extremities: Trace bilateral pedal edema, pulses intact

ASSESSMENT: 67-year-old with diabetes and hypertension for routine follow-up. Blood pressure slightly elevated - may need to increase lisinopril. Diabetes reasonably controlled. Due for routine diabetic monitoring labs including HbA1c, lipids, and kidney function.

PLAN: Increase lisinopril to 40mg daily for blood pressure control. Order HbA1c, comprehensive metabolic panel, lipid panel, and urine microalbumin/creatinine ratio. Follow-up in 3 months. Continue current diabetes management. Encouraged weight loss and low-sodium diet for blood pressure.

orders.failure_reason: Referral placed but in physician's task queue marked for 'next week' - not yet sent

results.full_text:
GLUCOSE: 168 mg/dL
SODIUM: 138 mEq/L
POTASSIUM: 5.2 mEq/L
CHLORIDE: 102 mEq/L
CO2: 22 mEq/L
BUN: 45 mg/dL (H) [normal 7-20]
CREATININE: 3.8 mg/dL (H) [normal 0.7-1.3]
eGFR: 16 mL/min/1.73m² (L) [normal >60]

CRITICAL: Acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease stage 4-5. Creatinine significantly elevated at 3.8 with eGFR of 16 indicating severe renal impairment. Immediate nephrology referral recommended. Review medications for renal dosing adjustments. Urgent follow-up needed.

Urine Albumin: 1,250 mg/g creatinine [normal <30]

INTERPRETATION: Severely elevated albuminuria consistent with diabetic nephropathy or other glomerular disease. In conjunction with reduced eGFR, indicates advanced kidney disease. Nephrology consultation recommended.
Hemoglobin A1c: 7.2% (Goal <7.0% for most diabetics)

diagnostic_hypothesis.reasoning: eGFR of 16 mL/min/1.73m² indicates stage 4-5 CKD (severe to end-stage). Severely elevated albuminuria (1,250 mg/g) with long-standing diabetes strongly suggests diabetic nephropathy. Patient approaching need for renal replacement therapy (dialysis threshold typically eGFR <15). Foamy urine reported by patient is classic sign of proteinuria.

clinical_note.text:
SUBJECTIVE: 52-year-old female presents with right breast lump found on self-exam 3 weeks ago. Initially thought it might be related to her menstrual cycle but it hasn't changed in size. Lump is in upper outer quadrant of right breast. Denies nipple discharge, skin changes, or pain. No prior history of breast biopsies. Last mammogram was 3 years ago (normal). Family history significant for maternal aunt with breast cancer at age 62.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: Normal
Breast Exam: 2.5 cm firm, irregular mass in upper outer quadrant of right breast at 10 o'clock position, approximately 5 cm from nipple. Mass feels fixed to underlying tissue. No skin dimpling or peau d'orange. No nipple retraction. No axillary lymphadenopathy palpable on right. Left breast exam normal.

ASSESSMENT: Right breast mass in 52-year-old female. Concerning features include firm, irregular consistency and fixed nature of mass. Family history of breast cancer increases risk. Requires triple assessment: clinical exam (done today), imaging, and tissue diagnosis.

PLAN: Order diagnostic mammogram with ultrasound of right breast. Depending on imaging characteristics (BI-RADS score), will likely need core needle biopsy. Referred to breast imaging center. Patient given information about breast cancer and what to expect. Follow-up appointment scheduled in 2 weeks to review results and discuss next steps.

orders.test_name: Diagnostic Mammogram with Ultrasound, Right Breast
Ultrasound-Guided Core Needle Biopsy, Right Breast
orders.failure_reason: Scheduled for 2 weeks out per standard protocol, but appointment slot was accidentally double-booked and patient not contacted to reschedule

results.full_text:
MAMMOGRAM FINDINGS:
Right breast demonstrates 2.8 cm irregular spiculated mass with associated microcalcifications in upper outer quadrant. Architectural distortion present. No axillary lymphadenopathy visible on imaging.

ULTRASOUND FINDINGS:
Corresponding to mammographic abnormality, there is a 2.8 x 2.2 x 2.4 cm irregular hypoechoic mass with poorly defined margins, posterior acoustic shadowing, and increased vascularity on Doppler. No simple cyst features.

BI-RADS ASSESSMENT: 5 - Highly Suggestive of Malignancy (>95% likelihood of cancer)

RECOMMENDATION: Urgent tissue diagnosis via core needle biopsy recommended. Findings are highly suspicious for invasive breast carcinoma. Surgical consultation should be expedited pending biopsy confirmation.

differential: Complex sclerosing lesion/radial scar (rare benign mimic)
diagnostic_hypothesis.reasoning: BI-RADS 5 lesion has >95% probability of malignancy. Spiculated margins with microcalcifications and posterior acoustic shadowing on ultrasound are classic features of invasive breast cancer. Core needle biopsy will confirm diagnosis and provide receptor status (ER/PR/HER2) to guide treatment.

failure_mode: Biopsy appointment double-booked and patient not rescheduled - 3-week delay resulted in tumor growth and lymph node spread, upstaging from IIA to IIB

clinical_note.text:
SUBJECTIVE: 28-year-old male presents with painless swelling of right testicle noticed 3 weeks ago. Reports testicle feels heavier than the left. Denies trauma, pain, fever, or urinary symptoms. No discharge. Sexually active with one partner. Concerned because swelling has not resolved.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: Normal
Genitourinary: Right testicle enlarged to approximately 1.5-2x normal size, firm, non-tender. Mass does not transilluminate. Left testicle normal size and consistency. No inguinal lymphadenopathy. Spermatic cord normal. No hydrocele or varicocele appreciated.

ASSESSMENT: Painless testicular mass in young male. Differential includes testicular cancer (germ cell tumor), epididymitis, hydrocele, or varicocele. Given painless nature, firmness, and failure to transilluminate, testicular cancer is the primary concern. Testicular cancer is most common solid organ malignancy in men aged 15-35.

PLAN: Testicular ultrasound to characterize mass. Tumor markers (AFP, beta-hCG, LDH) to aid in diagnosis and serve as baseline if cancer confirmed. Urgent urology referral. Advised patient that if ultrasound confirms solid mass, will likely need radical orchiectomy for both diagnosis and treatment. Explained excellent cure rate for testicular cancer even if advanced.

orders.failure_reason: Urology referral placed but patient never received appointment call due to referral coordinator being out sick

results.full_text:
RIGHT TESTICLE: Enlarged with heterogeneous 3.8 cm solid mass involving majority of testicular parenchyma. Mass is hypoechoic with increased vascularity. No cystic components. Findings consistent with primary testicular neoplasm.

LEFT TESTICLE: Normal size and echotexture. No masses.

IMPRESSION: 3.8 cm solid right testicular mass highly suspicious for germ cell tumor. Recommend urgent urology consultation for orchiectomy. CT chest/abdomen/pelvis recommended for staging.

ALPHA-FETOPROTEIN (AFP): 1,250 ng/mL (normal <10)
BETA-hCG: 850 mIU/mL (normal <5 in males)
LDH: 425 U/L (normal 140-280)

INTERPRETATION: Markedly elevated AFP and beta-hCG strongly support diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor, likely mixed germ cell tumor or embryonal carcinoma. Elevated markers indicate metastatic potential. Urgent surgical consultation and staging imaging essential. These markers will be used to monitor treatment response.

diagnostic_hypothesis.reasoning: Solid testicular mass on ultrasound in 28-year-old male with markedly elevated AFP (1,250) and beta-hCG (850) is diagnostic of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor. Seminoma does not produce AFP. Requires urgent orchiectomy for definitive diagnosis and staging CT to assess for metastases. Highly curable even when metastatic.

ground_truth_diagnosis: Stage IIB Mixed Germ Cell Tumor (Embryonal Carcinoma and Yolk Sac Tumor)
failure_mode: Staging CT delayed due to referral coordinator error - by time scheduled, patient had developed retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy requiring chemotherapy before surgery

CT chest/abdomen/pelvis ordered 9 days ago but never scheduled

clinical_note.text:
SUBJECTIVE: 81-year-old female brought by daughter for increasing confusion and weakness over past 2 weeks. Daughter reports mother has not been eating well, seems more tired, and has been 'not herself.' Patient reports feeling weak and dizzy when standing. Denies headache, vision changes, chest pain, or shortness of breath. No falls. Lives alone, usually independent with ADLs.

PMH: Hypertension, hypothyroidism
MEDICATIONS: Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily, Levothyroxine 100mcg daily

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 102/68 (sitting), 85/52 (standing), HR 88, Temp 98.0°F
General: Elderly female, appears fatigued, mildly confused
Mental Status: Oriented to person and place only, not to date. MMSE 22/30 (baseline unknown)
Cardiovascular: Regular rate, no murmurs
Neurologic: Decreased strength bilaterally (4/5), reflexes diminished
Skin: Poor skin turgor, dry mucous membranes

ASSESSMENT: 81-year-old with subacute confusion, weakness, orthostatic hypotension, and signs of dehydration. Differential includes dehydration, medication effect (HCTZ), urinary tract infection, hypothyroidism, electrolyte abnormality. Orthostatic hypotension concerning.

PLAN: Comprehensive metabolic panel to evaluate electrolytes and kidney function. TSH to check thyroid status. Urinalysis to rule out UTI. Hold hydrochlorothiazide temporarily given orthostatic hypotension. Encourage oral hydration. Daughter to monitor at home and call with any worsening. Follow-up in 3 days with lab results.

orders.failure_reason: Ordered STAT but imaging scheduler marked as routine - delayed

results.full_text:
SODIUM: 118 mEq/L (CRITICAL LOW) [normal 135-145]
POTASSIUM: 3.2 mEq/L
CHLORIDE: 82 mEq/L
CO2: 28 mEq/L
GLUCOSE: 92 mg/dL
BUN: 28 mg/dL
CREATININE: 1.4 mg/dL

CRITICAL ALERT: Severe hyponatremia (sodium 118). Symptoms of hyponatremia include confusion, weakness, and altered mental status - all present in this patient. Severe hyponatremia (<120) can cause seizures, coma, and death. Immediate medical attention required. Likely etiology: HCTZ-induced hyponatremia (thiazide diuretics are common cause in elderly). Recommend hospital admission for careful sodium correction with hypertonic saline. Do NOT correct too rapidly (risk of osmotic demyelination syndrome).
TSH: 2.4 mIU/L (normal 0.5-5.0)

diagnostic_hypothesis.reasoning: Sodium of 118 mEq/L is severe hyponatremia causing symptomatic confusion and weakness. Patient on HCTZ (thiazide diuretic), which is well-known cause of hyponatremia in elderly. Confusion, weakness, and orthostatic hypotension all explained by severe hyponatremia. Requires hospitalization for monitored sodium correction to prevent seizures and permanent neurologic damage.

SUBJECTIVE: 42-year-old male presents with left leg pain and swelling for 3 days. Reports pain started in calf and has progressively worsened. Leg feels tight and warm. Denies trauma. Recently returned from business trip to Singapore (14-hour flight) one week ago. No chest pain or shortness of breath. OBJECTIVE:

Left Lower Extremity: Calf circumference 3.5 cm larger than right, warmth to palpation, tenderness along deep venous system, positive Homan's sign. No erythema or streaking. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses intact.
Right Lower Extremity: Normal
Lungs: Clear bilaterally

ASSESSMENT: Left leg swelling and pain with recent long-haul flight and family history of VTE. Wells score for DVT: 5 points (moderate-high probability). Strong suspicion for deep vein thrombosis. Must rule out DVT given risk factors and clinical presentation.

PLAN: D-dimer and lower extremity venous duplex ultrasound to evaluate for DVT. If DVT confirmed, will start anticoagulation. Instructed patient not to massage leg and to return immediately if develops chest pain or shortness of breath (PE symptoms). Results should be available later today or tomorrow.

SUBJECTIVE: 16-year-old female presents with parents for severe headaches occurring 3-4 times per week for past 2 months. Describes headaches as throbbing, worse in morning, associated with nausea and vomiting. Reports visual changes - seeing double at times. Denies head trauma. Parents report she seems clumsier than usual, bumping into things. School performance declining. Menarche age 12, periods regular.

OBJECTIVE:

ASSESSMENT: 16-year-old with progressive headaches, papilledema, diplopia, and ataxia. Concerning for increased intracranial pressure. Differential includes brain tumor, pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension), hydrocephalus, or venous sinus thrombosis. Papilledema is serious finding requiring neuroimaging urgently.

PLAN: MRI brain with and without contrast to evaluate for mass lesion, hydrocephalus, or other structural abnormality. Neurology referral placed urgently. Parents counseled on red flag symptoms (severe worsening headache, decreased consciousness, seizure) and instructed to go to ER if these occur. Follow-up scheduled in 1 week or sooner after MRI results.

SUBJECTIVE: 63-year-old male presents with painless gross hematuria for 2 days. Reports urine is bright red, no clots. Denies dysuria, frequency, urgency, or flank pain. No recent trauma. No fevers. No prior episodes. Works in rubber manufacturing for 35 years (exposure to aniline dyes). Current smoker, 1 PPD x 40 years.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 142/86, HR 76, Temp 98.2°F
General: No acute distress
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no masses, no CVA tenderness
Genitourinary: External genitalia normal, no lesions

Urinalysis: >100 RBCs/hpf, no WBCs, no bacteria, no casts

ASSESSMENT: Painless gross hematuria in 63-year-old male smoker with occupational exposure to carcinogens (aniline dyes in rubber manufacturing). This is bladder cancer until proven otherwise. No evidence of infection (no WBCs, no bacteria). Lack of pain makes stone less likely.

PLAN: Cystoscopy to directly visualize bladder and identify source of bleeding. CT urography to evaluate entire urinary tract. Urine cytology. Urology referral placed. Patient counseled about concern for bladder cancer given risk factors. Advised to avoid NSAIDs and aspirin until cause identified.

FINDINGS: 2.8 cm irregular mass arising from right bladder wall, predominantly involving the right lateral wall and trigone. Mass demonstrates enhancement. Mild right-sided hydronephrosis suggesting possible involvement of right ureteral orifice. No upper tract masses. Kidneys enhance symmetrically. No lymphadenopathy.

IMPRESSION: Bladder mass highly suspicious for urothelial carcinoma (bladder cancer). Mild hydronephrosis concerning for tumor involvement of ureteral orifice. Recommend urgent cystoscopy with biopsy and possible transurethral resection. Tumor appears invasive given size and hydronephrosis.
INTERPRETATION: Atypical urothelial cells present. High-grade urothelial carcinoma cannot be excluded. Recommend correlation with cystoscopy and biopsy for definitive diagnosis.

ASSESSMENT: Newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation. CHA2DS2-VASc score is 6 (age 71, female, HTN, diabetes, CHF, prior MI) indicating high stroke risk. Patient requires anticoagulation to prevent stroke. Rate control adequate on current beta blocker.

PLAN: Start apixaban 5mg BID for stroke prevention. Discussed risks and benefits of anticoagulation including bleeding risk. Patient agrees to start therapy. Continue metoprolol for rate control. Echocardiogram to assess for left atrial thrombus before considering cardioversion in future. Follow-up in 4 weeks.

SUBJECTIVE: 54-year-old male presents for persistent jaundice and pruritus for 3 weeks. Reports dark urine and pale stools. Significant weight loss of 20 pounds over past 2 months. Vague upper abdominal discomfort. Denies fever, nausea, or vomiting. No alcohol use. New-onset diabetes diagnosed 4 months ago.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 132/78, HR 82, Temp 98.4°F, Weight 165 lbs (down from 185 lbs)
General: Jaundiced, appears fatigued
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, palpable non-tender gallbladder (Courvoisier sign positive)
Skin: Icteric, excoriations from scratching

Labs (from today):
Total Bilirubin: 8.2 mg/dL (normal 0.3-1.2)
Direct Bilirubin: 6.8 mg/dL
Alkaline Phosphatase: 485 U/L (normal 30-120)
AST: 95 U/L
ALT: 112 U/L
CA 19-9: 850 U/mL (normal <37)

ASSESSMENT: Painless jaundice with palpable gallbladder (Courvoisier sign), weight loss, new-onset diabetes, and elevated CA 19-9 is pancreatic cancer until proven otherwise. Cholestatic pattern on labs. CA 19-9 markedly elevated.

PLAN: CT abdomen with pancreatic protocol to evaluate for pancreatic mass. ERCP may be needed for biliary decompression and tissue diagnosis. Oncology and hepatobiliary surgery referrals. Patient counseled about concern for pancreatic malignancy.

results.full_text:
FINDINGS: 3.5 cm hypoenhancing mass in head of pancreas causing obstruction of common bile duct and pancreatic duct (double duct sign). Mass encases superior mesenteric artery (>180 degrees). Dilated intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. Multiple enlarged peripancreatic lymph nodes. No definite liver metastases. Small amount of ascites.

IMPRESSION: Pancreatic head mass consistent with pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Vascular encasement (SMA >180°) indicates locally advanced, borderline resectable or unresectable disease. Recommend tissue diagnosis via ERCP or EUS-guided biopsy. Urgent oncology and hepatobiliary surgery consultation for staging and treatment planning. Prognosis poor given locally advanced disease.

CA 19-9 of 850 strongly supports malignancy. CT shows locally advanced disease with vascular involvement - poor prognosis. Requires urgent tissue diagnosis and multidisciplinary tumor board.

SUBJECTIVE: 8-year-old male brought by mother for persistent limp and right leg pain for 4 weeks. Initially thought to be from sports injury (soccer) but hasn't improved. Pain worse at night, sometimes wakes child from sleep. Acetaminophen helps somewhat. Denies fever or recent illness. Eating and growing normally.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 102/64, HR 88, Temp 98.2°F
Musculoskeletal: Antalgic gait favoring right leg. Tenderness over right distal femur. Firm, non-mobile mass palpable over distal femur, approximately 5 cm in size. No warmth or erythema. Range of motion of knee mildly limited by pain.
Neurologic: Strength intact, reflexes normal
No lymphadenopathy

ASSESSMENT: 8-year-old with persistent leg pain, night pain, and palpable bone mass. Concerning features for bone tumor include age, location (distal femur), night pain, and palpable mass. Differential includes osteosarcoma (most common primary bone cancer in children), Ewing sarcoma, or benign bone lesion (osteochondroma, bone cyst). Night pain is red flag for malignancy.

PLAN: X-ray right femur to evaluate for bone lesion. If abnormal, will need MRI for further characterization. Orthopedic oncology referral if imaging concerning. Parents counseled about possibility of bone tumor and need for prompt evaluation.

FINDINGS: Aggressive-appearing lesion in distal right femur metaphysis. Mixed lytic and sclerotic bone destruction with 'sunburst' periosteal reaction and Codman triangle. Soft tissue mass extending beyond cortex. No pathologic fracture.

IMPRESSION: Highly concerning for primary bone malignancy, most likely osteosarcoma given patient age, location (distal femur - most common site), and radiographic appearance. 'Sunburst' pattern is classic for osteosarcoma. Recommend urgent MRI for extent of disease and orthopedic oncology referral. Biopsy will be required for definitive diagnosis. Chest CT needed to evaluate for pulmonary metastases (osteosarcoma metastasizes to lungs).

Age 10-20 is peak incidence, distal femur is most common site. Night pain and palpable mass are concerning features. Requires urgent MRI for surgical planning and chest CT for staging. Treatment is neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by limb-salvage surgery.

PLAN: Non-contrast CT head to evaluate for hemorrhage. If CT negative, will need lumbar puncture to rule out SAH (xanthochromia can be present even with negative CT). Neurology consultation. Pain control with IV medications. Blood pressure management as needed.

results.full_text:
FINDINGS: No acute intracranial hemorrhage. No mass effect or midline shift. Ventricles normal size. No extra-axial fluid collections. Visualized paranasal sinuses clear.

IMPRESSION: No acute intracranial abnormality. Normal CT head.

NOTE: CT sensitivity for subarachnoid hemorrhage decreases with time. Sensitivity is 95-100% if performed within 6 hours but drops to 50% by 1 week. Given clinical concern for SAH with thunderclap headache, recommend lumbar puncture if CT performed >6 hours from symptom onset OR if high clinical suspicion persists despite negative CT. Xanthochromia (yellow CSF from RBC breakdown) develops 6-12 hours after bleed and can detect SAH missed by CT.

clinical_note.text:
SUBJECTIVE: 47-year-old female presents for thyroid nodule evaluation. Noticed lump in neck 2 months ago. Denies difficulty swallowing, voice changes, or shortness of breath. No family history of thyroid cancer. No prior radiation exposure. Feels well otherwise.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 122/78, HR 72, Temp 98.4°F
Thyroid: 2.5 cm firm nodule in right lobe, moves with swallowing. No cervical lymphadenopathy palpable.
ENT: Vocal cords mobile and normal on indirect laryngoscopy

Thyroid ultrasound (from PCP):
Right lobe: 3.2 x 2.8 x 2.5 cm hypoechoic nodule with irregular margins, microcalcifications present, taller-than-wide shape, increased vascularity. ACR TI-RADS 5 (high suspicion).
Left lobe: Normal
No pathologic lymph nodes

TSH: 1.8 mIU/L (normal)

ASSESSMENT: Thyroid nodule with highly suspicious ultrasound features (TI-RADS 5). Microcalcifications, irregular margins, and taller-than-wide shape are concerning for papillary thyroid carcinoma. Normal TSH indicates non-functioning nodule. Requires tissue diagnosis.

PLAN: Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy of right thyroid nodule. If malignant, will need total thyroidectomy. Baseline thyroglobulin. Discussed findings and next steps with patient.

SPECIMEN: Ultrasound-guided FNA, right thyroid nodule

CYTOLOGY: Cellular aspirate showing papillary architecture with cells demonstrating nuclear grooves, nuclear pseudoinclusions, and overlapping nuclei. Psammoma bodies present.

DIAGNOSIS: Bethesda VI - Malignant
Consistent with Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma

COMMENT: Papillary carcinoma is confirmed. Clinical correlation recommended. Recommend surgical consultation for total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection. Molecular testing not indicated given diagnostic cytology. Excellent prognosis with appropriate surgical management.

Excellent long-term prognosis with proper treatment.

clinical_note.text:
SUBJECTIVE: 35-year-old male presents with persistent headaches for 6 weeks. Describes headaches as worse in the morning, improves throughout the day. Associated with nausea, especially in morning. Reports visual changes - occasional blurred vision and double vision. Denies trauma. Works as software engineer, attributes symptoms initially to stress and screen time.

OBJECTIVE:
Vitals: BP 158/92, HR 88, Temp 98.4°F
Neurologic: 
- Mental status: Alert, oriented x3
- Cranial nerves: CN VI palsy noted bilaterally (limited abduction both eyes), other CNs intact
- Motor: 5/5 strength throughout
- Sensory: Intact
- Cerebellar: Mild dysmetria on finger-to-nose bilaterally
- Fundoscopy: Bilateral papilledema with blurred disc margins

ASSESSMENT: Morning headaches with nausea, papilledema, and CN VI palsies concerning for increased intracranial pressure. Sixth nerve palsies are false localizing signs of elevated ICP. Differential includes brain tumor, idiopathic intracranial hypertension (less likely in male), hydrocephalus, or cerebral venous thrombosis. Papilledema requires urgent neuroimaging.

PLAN: MRI brain with and without contrast to evaluate for mass lesion or hydrocephalus. Neurology referral urgently. BP elevated - may be reactive to ICP. Advised to go to ER immediately if headache suddenly worsens, vision loss, or seizure occurs. Avoid aspirin or NSAIDs until imaging complete.
